title: Historical Stock Price Performance of Telefonaktiebolaget LM Ericsson During Significant Market Events

content.text: The dot-com bubble burst in 2000 was a significant market event that had a profound impact on technology stocks, including LM Ericsson. During this period, the stock experienced a sharp decline in its price, as investor confidence in technology companies waned. From January 2000 to March 2003, Ericsson's stock price fell from around $110 to a low of $4. This represented a decline of over 95% and reflected the overall market sentiment during the dot-com crash.

Following the dot-com crash, the global economy entered a period of recovery, leading to a market rally. LM Ericsson's stock price also benefited from this positive market sentiment. From March 2003 to October 2007, the stock price gradually recovered, reaching a high of nearly $40. This represented a significant increase from the lows of the dot-com crash, and demonstrated investor confidence in the company's prospects amid improving economic conditions.

The global financial crisis of 2008 had a severe impact on stock markets worldwide, including LM Ericsson. During this period of market turmoil, the stock price experienced a significant decline. From October 2007 to February 2009, Ericsson's stock price dropped from around $40 to a low of approximately $6. This decline of nearly 85% was primarily driven by concerns about the global economy, credit market freeze, and reduced spending on telecom equipment by companies.

Following the global financial crisis, stock markets gradually recovered as economies stabilized. LM Ericsson's stock price also benefited from this post-crisis rally. From February 2009 to May 2015, the stock price steadily increased, reaching a peak of around $15. This represented a significant recovery from the lows of the financial crisis, and reflected renewed confidence in the company's ability to navigate challenging market conditions and adapt to changes in the telecommunications industry.

The outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic in early 2020 caused a global market crash, affecting stocks of various industries, including LM Ericsson. From February to March 2020, the stock price witnessed a steep decline. During this period, Ericsson's stock fell from around $9 to a low of approximately $6. The market crash was primarily driven by widespread uncertainty, economic disruptions, and reduced business activity due to lockdown measures implemented to contain the spread of the virus.

news.headline: AT&T’s Ericsson Supply Deal Isn’t ‘Secret Sauce’ for Easing Costs, CEO Says
news.summary: AT&T's new [$14 billion supply deal with Ericsson](https://www.wsj.com/business/telecom/at-t-signs-14-billion-supply-deal-with-ericsson-e0d870dd) could save money but won't give the cellphone carrier a "secret sauce" for thinning out expenses, its CEO said Tuesday.  Speaking to a UBS investor conference, CEO John Stankey said "capital intensity" should still fall between $21 billion and $22 billion next year, suggesting that Ericsson savings will cover other spending priorities.  The new deal will move AT&T away from Nokia equipment in many markets.

news.headline: Why AT&T Stock Is Up Today
news.summary: AT&T (NYSE: T) is betting big on new open-source telecom equipment that it says will save it billions over time.  Investors are excited about the development, sending AT&T shares up about 3% as of 11 a.m. ET Tuesday.  AT&T has agreed to buy upwards of $14 billion worth of hardware and services from Swedish equipment supplier Ericsson (NASDAQ: ERIC), part of the company's transition away from proprietary technology and toward what is known as Open and Interoperable Radio Access Network tech, or Open RAN.

news.headline: AT&T to Accelerate Open and Interoperable Radio Access Networks (RAN) in the United States through new collaboration with Ericsson
news.summary: AT&T today announced plans to lead the United States in commercial scale open radio access network (Open RAN) deployment. This industry-leading move, in collaboration with Ericsson, will further the telecommunications industry efforts and build a more robust ecosystem of network infrastructure providers and suppliers. AT&T's spend could approach roughly $14 billion over the 5-year term of the contract with Ericsson.

news.headline: UPDATE 1-AT&T chooses Ericsson for new US telecom network, will drop Nokia
news.summary: AT&T said on Monday it chose Ericsson to build a telecom network that uses only so-called ORAN technology and which will cover 70% of its wireless traffic in the United States by late 2026, marking a milestone for the new technology.  ORAN or open radio access network promises to cut costs drastically for telecom operators as it uses cloud-based software and gear from many suppliers instead of relying on proprietary equipment supplied by such companies as Nokia , Ericsson and Huawei which do not work with each other.

news.headline: Intel Scores a Manufacturing Win With Ericsson Networking Chips
news.summary: Chip giant Intel (NASDAQ: INTC) is investing billions of dollars in building its own foundry business.  The real payoff won't come until 2025 at the earliest when its Intel 18A process node, expected by Intel to be the best in the industry, enters full-scale production.  In addition to the Intel 18A process, the company's foundry arm advertises the cost-effective Intel 16 process for chips that don't need cutting-edge manufacturing tech, as well as the upcoming Intel 3 process.

news.headline: Ericsson Mobility Report: Resilient 5G uptake - global mobile data traffic set to triple in six years
news.summary: Ericsson (NASDAQ: ERIC) estimates that almost one-in-five of all global mobile subscriptions will be 5G subscriptions by the end of 2023, as the growth proves resilient despite continued economic challenges and geopolitical unrest in some markets.
